description.narrative: Countries supported with strengthening AIDS responses in relation to human rights, addressing stigma and discrimination and ensuring treatment, care and support.

comment.narrative: Discriminatory legal regulatory and policy environments for PLHIV and key populations in several countries of the region including, drug use , sex work and same sex relationships. Shrinking funding for CSO to conduct HIV related activities
7 countries supported with strengthening AIDS responses in relation to human rights, addressing stigma and discrimination and ensuring treatment, care and support.

Selected results include: - Sudan: an LEA was conducted in 2018 and some key recommendations have already been implemented. For example, Sudan revoked some of the laws that were previously used against PLHIV and KPs. To follow up on this, UNDP is supporting mainstreaming IV into the Ministry of Justice law and policy reform that is currently being implemented as part of the political transition. UNDP is also supporting the engagement and capacity building of human rights activists and civil society organizations who are the first line of defense against violations of human rights of PLHIV and KPs. - Tunisia: UNDP supported the development of a Chapter on Human Rights in the new NSP 2021-2023. This support come at a very important juncture of the national response as the new NSP was used to inform the development of the concept note of the Global Fund NFM3. The development of the human rights chapter was developed in full consultation and collaboration with civil society organizations, PLHIV representative and key populations. The human rights chapter will also guide the Global Fund interventions. - Algeria: UNDP supported the development of an HIV and Human Rights Strategy, which will inform the national HIV response over the next few years. The strategy was developed in consultation with relevant stakeholders in the government, UN joint team on HIV and key civil society stakeholders. The strategy will also inform the transition of the HIV response from the GF to domestic funding.
Technical support provided to 7 countries implementing catalytic and policy support for the national HIV responses.

UNDP Lead a Gender Justice exercise in 2018, along side UNWomen and UNFPA, followed by series of national consultations conducted in the 20 countries included in the assessment. In Jordan and Lebanon, following the consultations, the articles 522 and 308 were both repelled by the Parliaments of the two countries. Following comprehensive campaigns by civil society organizations and media. This important law reform was made possible after UNDP shed the light on these practices and gaps in the laws. UNDP supported the creation of the NAWARA Network of Vulnerable Women in MENA. The network was represented by women from 12 countries (including Iran, Afghanistan and Pakistan), and its mandate is to analyze and research the root causes of vulnerabilities including GBV, economic disempowerment and financial exclusion and advocate for better Health and Wellbeing of Women. UNDP supported Legal Environment Assessment (LEA) in each of Sudan and Somalia, with participation of civil society, PLHIV associations and governments. UNDP also supported the enhancement of national legal aid capacity through development of a core team of 30 young legal aid professionals (from Ministry of Justice and CSOs) who were linked up with the Sudanese People’s Living with HIV Care Association (SPCA) for provision of legal aid pro bono. Additionally, a national mechanism for documenting and reporting Human Rights violations will be established in 2020, and will be linked up with the national Human Rights Commission.
Tobacco control and NCDs: UNDP supported the development of Tobacco investment cases in each of Jordan and Egypt. The major findings include loss of 6.84% and 2.1% of the national GDP in Jordan and Egypt respectively. This work was done in partnership with the FCTC secretariat and WHO.
Through technical and operational support from UNDP, Egypt managed to regain access to the Global Fund resources to fund its national HIV and TB responses. UNDP became the interim principle recipient to the USD 2 million grant which will help bridge the gap in the national response especially on the prevention.
Inclusive Social Protection: technical support was provided to the Sudanese Ministry of Social Welfare (MoSW) and the Sudanese People Living with HIV Care Association (SPCA) to resolve the challenge of targeting PLHIV with social protection packages. With advocacy and lobbying, MoSW applied special enrollment procedure for PLHIV in the Social Health Insurance scheme, funded by the government.

Technical and policy support provided to 7 countries through catalytic and policy-targeted support to address gaps in their national HIV responses, focusing on key population, legal and policy challenges.

UNDP spearheaded the response to COVID-19 in 2020, with the pandemic hitting hard the already stretched health systems in the region. UNDP coordinated a response in the Arab States region out of the Amman Regional Hub, where support provided to all countries including: Procurement of PPEs and ventilators, repurposing existing grants to avail resources, resource mobilization and surge capacities deployment. In particular, UNDP supported the partial repurposing of the Global Fund grants in Sudan, Egypt and Djibouti which allowed significant resources for procurement of PPEs and other important COVID-19 equipment. UNDP also supported the Socioeconomic Impact Assessment (SIA) and mitigation measures. In Egypt, UNDP conducted an assessment of the sustainability of HIV prevention, care and treatment services for PLHIV and KPs during health crises, including but not limited to COVID-19. The findings of the assessment will also be used to inform the design of the next Global Fund grant application in Egypt (due June 2021). UNDP supported the mitigation of COVID-19 impact on Women living with HIV in Djibouti, where the COVID-19 imposed double burden on them; loss of livelihoods and vulnerability to infection. To address that, UNDP supported the technology and skills transfer of the manufacturing of simple Personal Protection Equipment (PPE), mainly masks to be to produced by women living with HIV, resulting in immediate boosting of their livelihoods during difficult times. In Sudan, while UNDP has mobilized significant resources through reprogramming of GF grants and supported the procurement of the essential PPEs for the COVID-19 response. Additionally, UNDP mobilized additional resources from the United Nations’, African Union Hybrid Mission in Darfur (UNAMID) to boost the COVID-19 treatment facilities in Sudan through procurement of additional ICU beds with equipment and ventilators. Prisoners and other people in closed settings were at highest risk of COVID-19 in Morocco due to crowding and lack of adequate health care. UNDP collaborated with UNODC to procure and distribute PPEs in the prisons for the inmates and the staff. While catering for the pressing COVID-19 needs, UNDP continued it is regular policy support to promote effective and inclusive governance for health, in Sudan and Somalia, following the successful implementation of the LEA, UNDP supported the implementation of the recommendations, including repletion of some punitive laws in Sudan and addressing policy barriers in Somalia. In the Gulf states, UNDP supported the conducting of NCDs related investment cases in each of Bahrain, Oman and Kuwait as the first group of the 6 Gulf nations. This was a result of a new collaboration with the Gulf Health Council, with promising follow up projects. The impact of COVID-19 goes beyond people to affect the planet, as the increase medical wastes resulting from the COVID-19 operations exceeded the capacities of the countries to deal with. UNDP supported a rapid assessment of HealthCare Waste Management (HCWM) in each of Sudan and Jordan as part of a global exercise. The findings of the assessment will be used for programmatic interventions at the policy and programme levels.
